history.content: Per our staff who hire GSIs: students who have been a GSI in a previous semester (and hence haven taken EE/CS 375) might have an advantage in the event the instructor wants them to GSI their course again, however we have plenty of first-time GSIs each semester.

children.subject: Since CS198 (hopefully soon-to-be CS370) has a maximum capacity of ~40 students, and we hire more than 200 GSI's each semester, it's apparent that you don't have to take the course in order to get a GSI appointment.  How helpful the course is depends on how well you did, as well as which courses you apply to GSI. For example, I think the course helps more if you apply to GSI a lower-division course (especially CS61A & CS61B) because the instructors can serve as a reference. Faculty contact me regarding some applications, and I can tell them if a particular student exhibited strong teaching potential.  Outside of those circumstances, I'm not sure how useful it is.  That being said, you should take the course to learn the content; students regularly report that the curriculum made them better teachers, and I'm hopeful that, over time, this will become readily apparent to hiring faculty--thus making the course even more useful than it currently is.

history.content:
I realize there's no concrete answer for this, but I'd kind of hoping to get some general sense of how this should stack up against some other opportunities, in terms of how much the time commitment is worth. Currently a course tutor, interested in TAing next fall; is there some general advice on how much/how little having taken this class will affect chances of getting a TA position?

Any input appreciated as I really have no idea about this. Thanks!
history.subject: How important is taking CS 370 (formally 198) wrt applying for a TA position?
